comments:
Introduction to medical anthropology takes central concepts in anthropology -- culture, adaptation, human variation, belief, political economy, the body -- and applies them to human health and illness. Students explore key elements of healing systems including healing technologies and healer-patient relationships. Modern day applications for medical anthropology are stressed.

Students commented that this course was “a good general introduction to concepts of medical anthropology,” and provided students with “ a whole new perspective on medicine.” Some students described the content as “really interesting,” but the lectures as “often boring.” Overall, most students acknowledged that they “enjoyed the course.” 

Student reviews of Professor Barg were mixed. Some students described Professor Barg as, “outstanding,” and excellent at making “class very interesting.” Other students commented that Professor Barg was “ineffective” at presenting material in an interesting manner, and “read word for word off PowerPoint [slides].”

Students commented that the “readings were extremely long,” and the assignments were necessary in order to “help keep students on track.” However, many students described the assignments as confusing and commented that grading was “pretty harsh and subjective.” This course was recommended for both majors and non-majors.
